subsection.title: Using the Normal Table
subsection.p: Values for z in the left column of the standard normal table are given in increments of 0.05. For z values that fall between rows of the table, use an area estimate that is between the corresponding values in the area column. For example, z=.77 is between the row for z=.75 with area 54.67 and the row for z=.80 with area 57.63, so a reasonable area estimate would be 56\%. Use a similar estimation procedure if you want to find a z value that corresponds to an area that falls between rows of the table. For example, the area 80\% falls between the row for area 78.87\% for z=1.25 and the row for the area 80.64\% for z=1.30, so a reasonable z estimate would be z=1.27 or z=1.28. The procedure of reading between the rows is not technical, and might be off by a little bit, but it is better than rounding off to the values in the nearest row.

When calculating a z value for normal data, you may round to the nearest 0.01, because that is the level of accuracy in the z column of the normal table. When calculating an area under the normal curve, you may usually round the final answer to the nearest whole percent. These practices are exceptions to the usual roundoff advice .

subsection.title: Examples
subsection.p:
Here are some basic problem types about the normal curve. Data called X is approximately normally distributed, with \AVE(X)=72.3 and \SD(X)=6.7.
(symmetric region) Estimate the percent of data in the range 72.3\pm 3.9.
(asymmetric region) Estimate the percent of data in the range 69.0 to 81.0.
(left tail region) Estimate the percentile rank for the data values 69.0 and 81.0.
(from area to z) Estimate the data values with 70th and 35th percentile ranks.
Here are the solutions. Here are the drawing method solution steps taught in the textbook.
The z values for 72.3\pm 3.9 are \pm \frac{3.9}{6.7} \approx \pm .58. The normal table shows that the area between these z values is about 44\%.
The z value for 69.0 is z_L=\frac{69.0-72.3}{6.7}\approx -.49, and the z value for 81.0 is z_R = \frac{81.0-72.3}{6.7}\approx 1.30. The corresponding areas in the normal table are 38\% and 81\%, respectively. The area from z_L to 0 is about 38/2=19\% and the area from 0 to z_R is about 81/2=40.5\%, so the area from z_L to z_R is about 19+40.5=59.5\%\approx 60\%.
We have the same values z_L,z_R from the previous part. First, we consider z_L=-.49. Start with the observation that 100\% \amp = (\text{area to the left of }-.49) \amp + (\text{area between }-.49 \text{ and }+.49) \amp + (\text{area to the right of }+4.9).
By mirror symmetry, we have (\text{area to the left of }-.49) = (\text{area to the right of }+4.9). Putting these together, we get (\text{area to the left of }-.49)= \frac{100\%-(\text{area between }-.49 \text{ and }+.49)}{2} which is (100 -38)/2=31\%. Next, we consider z_R=1.30. Start with (\text{area to the left of }1.30)\amp = (\text{area left of }0) \amp + (\text{area between }0 \text{ and }1.30) \amp = 50\% + 81/2 \amp \approx 90\%.
First, we find the z value that has 70th percentile rank. Let's call that value A. Starting with the observation that 100\% \amp = (\text{area to the left of }A) \amp + (\text{area to the right of }A) \amp = 70 + (\text{area to the right of }A)
we conclude that the area to the right of A is 30\%. By mirror symmetry, it must be that the area to the left of -A is also 30\%, so the area between -A and +A must be 100 - 2(30) = 40\%. Using the normal curve table, we find that A\approx .52. This converts to an X value of X=(.52)(6.7)+72.3\approx 75.8. Next, we find a z value that has 35th percentile rank. Let's call that value -B (so that -B is to the left of average, and +B is to the right of average). Starting with 100\% \amp = (\text{area to the left of }-B) \amp + (\text{area between }-B \text{ and }B) \amp + (\text{area to the right of }B)
By mirror symmetry, we have (\text{area to the left of }-B) = (\text{area to the right of }B). It follows that both sides of this equation are 35\%, so we conclude that (\text{area between }-B \text{ and }B)= 100 - 2(35)=30\%. From the normal table, we get -B\approx -.385. This converts to an X value of X=(-.385)(6.7)+72.3\approx 69.7.
